Danilo Cavalcante

Danilo Cavalcante is a Brazilian fugitive and convicted murderer, known for his involvement in several high-profile crimes, including the alleged murder of Valter Júnior Moreira dos Reis in 2017 and the confirmed murder of Deborah Brandão in 2021. His cases have garnered significant media attention due to the brutality of the crimes and his subsequent prison escape in 2023.

#Early life

Danilo Cavalcante was born in Brazil, with little information available about his childhood, family, or upbringing. His life took a turn for the worse when he became involved in a life of crime, which would eventually lead to his notoriety.

#Alleged 2017 murder of Valter Júnior Moreira dos Reis

In 2017, Cavalcante was accused of murdering Valter Júnior Moreira dos Reis, a Brazilian man whose body was found in a forested area. The investigation suggested that Cavalcante was involved in the crime, but he denied any wrongdoing. The case drew widespread attention in Brazil due to the brutality of the crime and the lack of leads in the investigation. Although Cavalcante was the primary suspect, he was not convicted due to insufficient evidence.

#Escape to the United States

Following the investigation into the murder of Valter Júnior Moreira dos Reis, Cavalcante fled to the United States, where he lived under an assumed identity. During his time in the US, he managed to evade law enforcement and continue his life without drawing attention to himself. However, his life of crime eventually caught up with him.

#2021 murder of Deborah Brandão

On January 1, 2021, Cavalcante was arrested and charged with the murder of Deborah Brandão, a 19-year-old woman whose body was found in an apartment in Orange County, Florida. The investigation revealed that Cavalcante had a prior relationship with the victim and had a history of domestic violence. He was subsequently convicted of the crime and sentenced to life in prison.

#2023 prison escape

On January 31, 2023, Cavalcante escaped from the Orange County Jail in Florida, where he was being held for the murder of Deborah Brandão. The escape was described as a "sophisticated" plan, with Cavalcante using a homemade tool to break free from his cell and then escaping through a ventilation shaft.

##Manhunt

Following the escape, a massive manhunt was launched to capture Cavalcante. The Orange County Sheriff's Office, along with the US Marshals Service, launched a search effort that included air and ground units. The manhunt was extensive, with authorities searching for Cavalcante in several counties across Florida.

##Capture

On February 10, 2023, Cavalcante was captured in a wooded area in Osceola County, Florida, after a tip from a local resident led authorities to his location. He was taken into custody without incident and was subsequently returned to the Orange County Jail.

##Aftermath

The escape and subsequent capture of Cavalcante raised concerns about the security of the Orange County Jail and the protocols in place to prevent such incidents. An investigation was launched to determine how Cavalcante was able to escape and what measures could be taken to prevent similar incidents in the future.

#Notes

Danilo Cavalcante's case has been the subject of widespread media attention due to the brutality of his crimes and his ability to evade law enforcement. His prison escape in 2023 highlighted the need for improved security measures in correctional facilities and the importance of effective communication between law enforcement agencies.

Spare (memoir)

Spare is a memoir written by Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, which was released on January 10, 2023. The book is a personal and introspective account of Prince Harry's life, covering his childhood, his time in the military, his relationships, and his experiences as a member of the British royal family.

#Background and writing

Prince Harry began writing Spare in 2020, with the assistance of ghostwriter J.R. Moehringer. The book is published by Penguin Random House and has been translated into 15 languages. The title "Spare" refers to Prince Harry's position as the younger brother of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, and the idea that he was seen as the "spare" heir, rather than the heir apparent.

Prince Harry has stated that he wrote the book as a way of telling his story and setting the record straight about his life and experiences. He has also said that he hopes the book will help to promote greater understanding and empathy for those who have experienced trauma and mental health issues.

#Synopsis

##Childhood and Diana's death

The book begins with Prince Harry's childhood, describing his early years as a member of the royal family and his close relationship with his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales. Prince Harry recounts the events leading up to his mother's death in a car accident in Paris in 1997, and the impact that her death had on him and his family.

Prince Harry describes the emotional pain and trauma that he experienced following his mother's death, and the ways in which he struggled to cope with his grief. He also writes about the support that he received from his family and friends, including his brother, Prince William, and his grandparents, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.

##Teenage years, drug use, and deployment to Afghanistan

The book also covers Prince Harry's teenage years, including his time at Eton College and his experiences with drug use. Prince Harry writes candidly about his experimentation with cannabis and cocaine, and the ways in which he struggled with addiction.

Prince Harry also recounts his time in the British Army, including his deployment to Afghanistan in 2007-2008. He describes the experiences that he had during his time in the military, including the comrades that he lost and the traumatic events that he witnessed.

##Relationship with Charles and Camilla, William's wedding, and Caroline Flack

Prince Harry writes about his complicated relationship with his father, Charles, Prince of Wales, and his stepmother, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall. He describes the tension and distance that he feels towards his father, and the ways in which he has struggled to reconcile his feelings towards him.

The book also covers Prince Harry's attendance at his brother's wedding to Catherine Middleton in 2011, and his relationships with other members of the royal family. Prince Harry writes about his close friendship with the television presenter Caroline Flack, who died by suicide in 2020.

##Relationship with Meghan and fatherhood

Prince Harry writes extensively about his relationship with his wife, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, whom he met in 2016. He describes the ways in which they fell in love and the challenges that they faced as a couple, including the media scrutiny and the pressures of royal life.

Prince Harry also writes about the birth of their son, Archie Mountbatten-Windsor, in 2019, and the joys of fatherhood. He describes the ways in which becoming a father has changed him and given him a new sense of purpose.

##Stepping back from royal role

The book concludes with Prince Harry's decision to step back from his role as a senior member of the royal family, which he announced in 2020. Prince Harry writes about the reasons behind his decision, including the media scrutiny and the desire to protect his family and pursue a more private life.

#Release

Spare was released on January 10, 2023, and was widely anticipated and publicized. The book was released in multiple formats, including hardcover, e-book, and audiobook.

#Reception

##Sales

Spare has been a commercial success, with the book debuting at number one on the New York Times bestseller list. The book has also been a bestseller in other countries, including the United Kingdom and Canada.

##Critical response

The book has received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising Prince Harry's candor and vulnerability, while others have criticized the book for being too self-indulgent and lacking in depth.

##Afghanistan comments

Prince Harry's comments about his time in Afghanistan have been criticized by some, who have accused him of being insensitive and boastful. Prince Harry has apologized for any offense that he may have caused.

##Discussions on mental health

The book has sparked discussions about mental health and the importance of seeking help and support. Prince Harry has spoken publicly about his own struggles with mental health and the ways in which he has sought help.

##Political response

The book has been the subject of political controversy, with some politicians and commentators criticizing Prince Harry for his comments about the royal family and the media. Others have defended Prince Harry's right to express his opinions and tell his story.

##Public opinion

Public opinion about the book has been divided, with some people praising Prince Harry for his honesty and courage, while others have criticized him for being selfish and attention-seeking.

#Veracity of claims

Some of the claims made in the book have been disputed by other members of the royal family and by the media. Prince Harry has stood by his account and has said that he is telling his truth.

#In popular culture

Spare has been the subject of much media attention and public fascination, with the book being discussed and debated on social media, television, and radio.

Guts (Olivia Rodrigo Album)

Guts is the second studio album by American singer-songwriter Olivia Rodrigo, released on September 8, 2023, through Geffen Records and Interscope Records. The album marks a significant departure from Rodrigo's debut studio album, Sour (2021), in terms of its sound, style, and themes. Guts features a more experimental and mature approach to songwriting, incorporating a wide range of genres and exploring complex emotions and relationships.

#Background

Rodrigo began working on Guts in 2022, shortly after the release of her debut album Sour. She stated that she wanted to create an album that was more personal and introspective, exploring themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. Rodrigo has mentioned that she drew inspiration from various artists and genres, including Taylor Swift, Kacey Musgraves, and indie rock music.

#Writing and recording

Rodrigo co-wrote and co-produced the majority of the tracks on Guts with her frequent collaborator, Dan Nigro. The two musicians worked together to create a unique sound that blended elements of pop, rock, and electronic music. The recording process took place in various studios in Los Angeles and New York City, with Rodrigo and Nigro experimenting with different instruments and production techniques.

##Music

Guts features a diverse range of musical styles, from the introspective balladry of "Ballad of a Homeschooled Girl" to the upbeat, indie-rock influenced "Bad Idea Right?". The album's sound is characterized by Rodrigo's emotive vocals, intricate guitar work, and atmospheric production. Lyrically, the album explores themes of love, relationships, and self-discovery, with Rodrigo drawing on personal experiences and observations.

##Lyrics

The lyrics on Guts are notable for their complexity and nuance, with Rodrigo exploring themes of love, heartbreak, and identity. The album's lyrics are characterized by their introspection and emotional honesty, with Rodrigo drawing on personal experiences and observations. Tracks like "Making the Bed" and "Pretty Isn't Pretty" feature Rodrigo's signature confessional style, while songs like "Vampire" and "Teenage Dream" showcase her ability to craft catchy, memorable hooks.

#Release and promotion

Guts was released on September 8, 2023, through Geffen Records and Interscope Records. The album was preceded by a series of singles and promotional releases, including the lead single "Bad Idea Right?" and the promotional single "Vampire".

##Cover artwork

The cover artwork for Guts features a photograph of Rodrigo taken by photographer Zoey Grossman. The image depicts Rodrigo standing in a dimly lit room, surrounded by shadows and eerie lighting. The artwork has been praised for its moody, atmospheric aesthetic, which reflects the album's themes and sound.

##Singles

The lead single from Guts, "Bad Idea Right?", was released on July 14, 2023. The song was a commercial success, peaking at number 10 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart. The album's second single, "Pretty Isn't Pretty", was released on August 25, 2023, and peaked at number 20 on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart.

##Marketing

The marketing campaign for Guts included a series of promotional releases, social media teasers, and live performances. Rodrigo performed at various music festivals and concerts in the lead-up to the album's release, including the Governors Ball Music Festival and the iHeartRadio Music Festival.

##Tour

Rodrigo embarked on the Guts Tour in support of the album, with dates in North America, Europe, and Australia. The tour featured Rodrigo performing tracks from Guts, as well as songs from her debut album Sour.

##Guts: The Secret Tracks

In conjunction with the album's release, Rodrigo released a series of bonus tracks and remixes, titled Guts: The Secret Tracks. The release featured alternate versions of tracks from the album, as well as previously unreleased material.

#Critical reception

Guts received widespread critical acclaim upon its release. Reviewers praised the album's sound, style, and themes, with many noting Rodrigo's growth and maturity as a songwriter. The album holds a Metacritic score of 84 out of 100, based on 22 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".

##Year-end lists

Guts appeared on several year-end lists, including Rolling Stone's "50 Best Albums of 2023" and Billboard's "50 Best Albums of 2023".

#Commercial performance

Guts was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart and selling over 100,000 copies in its first week. The album also reached number one on the UK Albums Chart and the Australian Albums Chart.

#Accolades

Guts has been nominated for several awards, including the Grammy Award for Album of the Year and the American Music Award for Favorite Pop/Rock Album.

article:
Supriyo v. Union of India

The case of Supriyo v. Union of India is a landmark Indian Supreme Court case that deals with the issue of same-sex marriage and the rights of the LGBTQ+ community in India. The case was filed by a group of petitioners, including Supriyo, who sought recognition of their same-sex marriages and the protection of their rights under the Indian Constitution.

# Case summary

The petitioners in the case, Supriyo and others, argued that the Indian government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages was a violation of their fundamental rights under the Constitution, including the right to equality, freedom of expression, and the right to life and personal liberty. They also argued that the government's stance was discriminatory and in violation of international human rights norms.

## Intervenors

Several intervenors joined the case, including government agencies, religious organizations, and human rights groups.

### Government

The Union of India, represented by the Attorney General, argued that same-sex marriage was not recognized under Indian law and that the petitioners' demands were not constitutionally valid.

### Religious organisation

The Jamiat Ulema-e-Hind, a prominent Islamic organization, argued that same-sex marriage was against Islamic principles and that the court should not recognize it.

# Background

The case was filed in the context of growing demands for LGBTQ+ rights in India, including the recognition of same-sex marriage. The Indian government had previously refused to recognize same-sex marriages, citing cultural and religious norms.

# Written arguments

The petitioners and respondent submitted detailed written arguments to the court, outlining their positions on the issue.

## Petitioners

The petitioners argued that the Indian government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages was a violation of their fundamental rights under the Constitution.

### Fundamental rights

The petitioners argued that their right to equality, freedom of expression, and the right to life and personal liberty were being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Jurisdiction

The petitioners argued that the court had jurisdiction to decide on the issue of same-sex marriage, as it was a matter of constitutional importance.

#### Constitutional morality

The petitioners argued that the court should apply constitutional morality, rather than societal or religious norms, in deciding on the issue.

#### Right to equality

The petitioners argued that the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages was discriminatory and in violation of the right to equality.

#### Anti-discrimination

The petitioners argued that the government's stance was in violation of international human rights norms, including the principle of non-discrimination.

#### Freedom of expression

The petitioners argued that their right to freedom of expression was being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Right to life and personal liberty

The petitioners argued that their right to life and personal liberty was being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Freedom of conscience and religion

The petitioners argued that their right to freedom of conscience and religion was being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Right to marry

The petitioners argued that they had a fundamental right to marry, which was being denied to them by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

### Issues in secular marriage law

The petitioners argued that the Indian government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages was in violation of secular marriage law.

#### Non-equality

The petitioners argued that the government's stance was discriminatory and in violation of the principle of equality.

#### Violations of freedom of expression

The petitioners argued that their right to freedom of expression was being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Violations of decisional autonomy

The petitioners argued that their right to decisional autonomy was being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

### Representative and heirs

The petitioners argued that they should have the same rights as heterosexual couples, including the right to adopt children and inherit property.

### International treaties

The petitioners argued that India was a signatory to international human rights treaties, including the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which recognized the right to equality and non-discrimination.

### Soft Law

The petitioners argued that international soft law, including the Yogyakarta Principles, recognized the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals, including the right to marry.

### Obergefell v. Hodges (United States, 2015)

The petitioners cited the US Supreme Court's decision in Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognized the right to same-sex marriage under the US Constitution.

### Recognition of foreign marriage

The petitioners argued that India should recognize same-sex marriages performed in other countries.

### Citizenship of sexual and gender minority spouse

The petitioners argued that the Indian government should grant citizenship to the same-sex spouse of an Indian citizen.

### Legislative policy

The petitioners argued that the Indian government should adopt legislative policies that recognized the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals, including the right to marry.

#### Healthcare

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have access to healthcare, including mental health services.

#### Finance

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have access to financial services, including loans and credit.

#### Employment

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have access to employment opportunities, including job protection.

#### Housing

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have access to housing, including protection from eviction.

#### Parenthood

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have the right to adopt children and have access to reproductive healthcare.

#### Judicial proceedings

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals should have access to fair and impartial judicial proceedings.

### Entry and residence permits

The petitioners argued that the Indian government should grant entry and residence permits to same-sex spouses of Indian citizens.

### Social exclusion and violence

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals faced social exclusion and violence, including harassment and assault.

#### Housing, education and employment

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals faced discrimination in housing, education, and employment.

#### Effects of repression

The petitioners argued that the repression of LGBTQ+ individuals had negative effects on their mental and physical health.

#### Social assimilation through inclusive policies

The petitioners argued that inclusive policies, including recognition of same-sex marriage, would promote social assimilation and reduce discrimination.

### Economic cost of social exclusion

The petitioners argued that the social exclusion of LGBTQ+ individuals had economic costs, including lost productivity and revenue.

#### Emigration

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals may emigrate to countries that recognized their rights, resulting in a loss of talent and revenue.

#### Foreign revenue

The petitioners argued that India may lose foreign revenue due to its failure to recognize LGBTQ+ rights.

#### Health disparity

The petitioners argued that LGBTQ+ individuals faced health disparities, including higher rates of mental health problems and HIV/AIDS.

## Respondent

The respondent, the Union of India, argued that same-sex marriage was not recognized under Indian law and that the petitioners' demands were not constitutionally valid.

### Fundamental rights

The respondent argued that the petitioners' fundamental rights were not being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Right to life and personal liberty

The respondent argued that the petitioners' right to life and personal liberty was not being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

#### Right to freedom of conscience and religion

The respondent argued that the petitioners' right to freedom of conscience and religion was not being violated by the government's refusal to recognize their same-sex marriages.

### Constitutional exception to fundamental rights

The respondent argued that there were constitutional exceptions to the petitioners' fundamental rights, including the right to equality and non-discrimination.

#### Legitimate state interests

The respondent argued that the government had legitimate state interests in refusing to recognize same-sex marriage, including the protection of social and cultural norms.

##### Historical and religious norms

The respondent argued that same-sex marriage was not recognized under Indian law due to historical and religious norms.

##### Social values

The respondent argued that same-sex marriage was not recognized under Indian law due to social values, including the importance of family and marriage.

### International and comparative law

The respondent argued that international and comparative law did not support the recognition of same-sex marriage.

### Legislative policy

The respondent argued that the Indian government had adopted legislative policies that recognized the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals, including the right to equality and non-discrimination.

## Intervenors

Several intervenors joined the case, including government agencies, religious organizations, and human rights groups.

### National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

The National Commission for Protection of Child Rights argued that the recognition of same-sex marriage would have negative effects on children.

### Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights

The Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights argued that the recognition of same-sex marriage would have negative effects on children in Delhi.

#### Guidelines

The Delhi Commission for Protection of Child Rights argued that guidelines should be developed to protect the rights of children in same-sex families.

### Jamiat Ulema-e-Hind

The Jamiat Ulema-e-Hind argued that same-sex marriage was against Islamic principles and that the court should not recognize it.

### Telangana Markazi Shia Ulema Council

The Telangana Markazi Shia Ulema Council argued that same-sex marriage was against Islamic principles and that the court should not recognize it.

# Preliminary hearings

The court held preliminary hearings to consider the petitioners' demands and the respondent's arguments.

# Oral arguments

The court held oral arguments to consider the petitioners' demands and the respondent's arguments.

## Jurisdiction

The court considered whether it had jurisdiction to decide on the issue of same-sex marriage.

### Statutory Interpretation

The court considered whether the Indian law recognized same-sex marriage.

### Workability of law

The court considered whether the recognition of same-sex marriage would be workable under Indian law.

### Personal law

The court considered whether same-sex marriage was recognized under personal law in India.

## Right to marry

The court considered whether the petitioners had a fundamental right to marry.

## Sexual and gender minority rights

The court considered whether the recognition of same-sex marriage would promote the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals.

### Heteronormative framework

The court considered whether the Indian law was based on a heteronormative framework that excluded LGBTQ+ individuals.

### Procreation

The court considered whether the purpose of marriage was procreation and whether same-sex couples could procreate.

### Parenthood

The court considered whether same-sex couples could be parents and whether they should have the same rights as heterosexual couples.

## Cultural, social and religious values

article:
2023
================

2023 is a common year that has 365 days, starting on a Sunday. It is the 2023rd year of the Anno Domini (AD) era, the 23rd year of the 21st century, and the 4th year of the 2020s decade.

Events
========
### January

* January 1: Global New Year's Day celebrations took place, marking the beginning of 2023.
* January 5: The 118th United States Congress convened, with Democrats controlling the Senate and Republicans controlling the House of Representatives.
* January 8: A magnitude 6.0 earthquake struck the northern coast of Papua New Guinea, causing widespread damage and power outages.
* January 15: A Yeti Airlines ATR 72 aircraft crashed in Pokhara, Nepal, killing all 72 people on board.
* January 18: The European Union imposed new sanctions on Russia, targeting its energy and financial sectors, in response to its ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

### February

* February 2: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25% to combat inflation, marking its eighth rate hike since March 2022.
* February 6: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck southern Turkey and northern Syria, killing over 40,000 people and causing widespread destruction.
* February 10: The US shot down a Chinese spy balloon that had been flying over its airspace, sparking tensions between the two nations.
* February 15: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) announced that Russian and Belarusian athletes would be allowed to compete under a neutral flag at the 2024 Summer Olympics.

### March

* March 1: The Ukrainian government launched a counteroffensive against Russian forces in the eastern region of Donetsk.
* March 5: The US and South Korea began joint military exercises, prompting North Korea to conduct a series of missile tests.
* March 10: The Silicon Valley Bank collapsed, marking the largest US bank failure since the 2008 financial crisis.
* March 17: The International Criminal Court (ICC) issued an arrest warrant for Russian President Vladimir Putin, accusing him of war crimes in Ukraine.

### April

* April 2: The Israeli government passed a law that would allow it to override Supreme Court decisions, sparking widespread protests.
* April 5: The US and China held high-level talks in Beijing, aimed at easing tensions between the two nations.
* April 10: The Indian government launched a crackdown on opposition leaders and activists, ahead of the country's general election.
* April 15: A severe storm system swept across the southern United States, causing widespread damage and power outages.

### May

* May 1: Global May Day celebrations took place, with protests and rallies held in cities around the world.
* May 5: The UK held local elections, with the Conservative Party suffering significant losses.
* May 10: The US Supreme Court heard oral arguments in a case that could potentially overturn the landmark abortion ruling Roe v. Wade.
* May 15: The WHO declared the end of the COVID-19 pandemic, marking a major milestone in the global response to the virus.

### June

* June 1: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25% for the ninth time since March 2022.
* June 5: The European Central Bank raised interest rates by 0.25% to combat inflation in the eurozone.
* June 10: The US and Saudi Arabia signed a major arms deal, worth over $30 billion.
* June 15: The G7 summit took place in Hiroshima, Japan, with leaders discussing global issues such as climate change and economic inequality.

### July

* July 1: The UK and Australia signed a major free trade agreement, aimed at boosting economic ties between the two nations.
* July 5: The US celebrated Independence Day, marking the 247th anniversary of its founding.
* July 10: The European Union imposed new sanctions on Iran, targeting its energy and financial sectors, in response to its nuclear program.
* July 15: The US and Vietnam signed a major agreement on AI cooperation, aimed at boosting economic ties between the two nations.

### August

* August 1: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25% for the tenth time since March 2022.
* August 5: A magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck the Philippines, causing widespread damage and power outages.
* August 10: The US and South Korea began joint military exercises, prompting North Korea to conduct a series of missile tests.
* August 15: The Indian government launched a crackdown on opposition leaders and activists, ahead of the country's general election.

### September

* September 1: The US and China held high-level talks in Beijing, aimed at easing tensions between the two nations.
* September 5: The European Central Bank raised interest rates by 0.25% to combat inflation in the eurozone.
* September 10: The US Supreme Court began its new term, with a number of high-profile cases on the docket.
* September 15: The G20 summit took place in New Delhi, India, with leaders discussing global issues such as climate change and economic inequality.

### October

* October 1: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25% for the eleventh time since March 2022.
* October 5: The UK held a general election, with the Conservative Party losing its majority.
* October 10: The US and Saudi Arabia signed a major arms deal, worth over $30 billion.
* October 15: The WHO declared a global health emergency due to a outbreak of a new virus in Africa.

### November

* November 1: The US celebrated Election Day, with a number of high-profile midterm elections taking place.
* November 5: The US and China held high-level talks in Beijing, aimed at easing tensions between the two nations.
* November 10: The European Central Bank raised interest rates by 0.25% to combat inflation in the eurozone.
* November 15: The G7 summit took place in Tokyo, Japan, with leaders discussing global issues such as climate change and economic inequality.

### December

* December 1: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.25% for the twelfth time since March 2022.
* December 5: The US Supreme Court heard oral arguments in a case that could potentially overturn the landmark abortion ruling Roe v. Wade.
* December 10: The European Union imposed new sanctions on Russia, targeting its energy and financial sectors, in response to its ongoing invasion of Ukraine.
* December 15: The G20 summit took place in Buenos Aires, Argentina, with leaders discussing global issues such as climate change and economic inequality.

Demographics
=============

The world population is projected to reach 7.9 billion people by the end of 2023, with an average annual growth rate of 1.05%. The population of the United States is projected to reach 334 million people, while the population of China is projected to reach 1.44 billion people.

Best-selling media

* "Spare" by Prince Harry

article:
2022 IHF Women's U20 Handball World Championship

The 2022 IHF Women's U20 Handball World Championship was the 23rd edition of the IHF Women's Junior World Championship, the premier international women's junior handball tournament. The tournament was organized by the International Handball Federation (IHF) and took place in Slovenia from 22 June to 3 July 2022.

# Bidding process

The bidding process for the 2022 IHF Women's U20 Handball World Championship began in 2018, with several countries expressing interest in hosting the tournament. Slovenia was officially awarded the hosting rights in 2019, after a vote by the IHF Council.

# Qualification

Qualification for the tournament was based on the results of the 2020 IHF Women's U19 World Championship, as well as continental championships and tournaments. A total of 32 teams qualified for the tournament, with Slovenia receiving automatic qualification as the host nation.

# Venues

The tournament was played across four venues in Slovenia:

* Arena Stožice in Ljubljana
* Tivoli Hall in Ljubljana
* Zlatorog Arena in Celje
* Golovec Hall in Celje

# Draw

The draw for the tournament took place on 19 May 2022 in Ljubljana, Slovenia.

## Seeding

The teams were seeded based on their performance at the 2020 IHF Women's U19 World Championship. The top 12 teams from the previous tournament were seeded into the first four groups, while the remaining teams were seeded into the last four groups.

article:
Drishyam 2 (2022 film)

Drishyam 2 is a 2022 Indian Malayalam-language crime thriller film written and directed by Jeethu Joseph. The film is a sequel to the 2013 film Drishyam, and stars Mohanlal, Meena, Ansiba Hassan, Esther Anil, and Murali Gopy reprising their roles from the original film. The movie follows the story of Georgekutty and his family as they face new challenges and struggles six years after the events of the first film.

#Plot

The film picks up six years after the events of the first film, with Georgekutty (Mohanlal) now running a successful cinema hall and living a peaceful life with his family. However, his life takes a dramatic turn when he is investigated by a new police officer, Thomas Mathew (Murali Gopy), who is determined to solve the mystery of the missing boy, Varun. As Georgekutty tries to cover his tracks and protect his family, he must use all his wits and resourcefulness to outsmart the police and keep his dark secret buried.

Meanwhile, Rani (Meena), Georgekutty's wife, is struggling to come to terms with the past and the consequences of their actions. She is haunted by the memories of the missing boy and the guilt of their involvement in his disappearance. As the investigation intensifies, Rani's mental state begins to deteriorate, and Georgekutty must find a way to support her and keep their family together.

The film takes a thrilling turn as Georgekutty's past mistakes come back to haunt him, and he must face the consequences of his actions. With the police closing in on him, Georgekutty must use all his skills and experience to stay one step ahead of the law and protect his family.

#Cast

* Mohanlal as Georgekutty
* Meena as Rani Georgekutty
* Ansiba Hassan as Anju Georgekutty
* Esther Anil as Anu Georgekutty
* Murali Gopy as Thomas Mathew
* Sai Kumar as Suresh Babu
* Dileesh Pothan as Philip Mathew
* Asha Sharath as Geetha Prabhakar
* Siddique as Prabhakar

#Production

The film was announced in October 2020, with Jeethu Joseph confirming that he would be writing and directing the sequel to Drishyam. The film was produced by Antony Perumbavoor under the banner of Aashirvad Cinemas. The movie was shot on location in Thodupuzha, Kerala, and was completed in March 2022.

The film's script was written by Jeethu Joseph, who has said that he was inspired by the success of the first film and wanted to explore the characters further. The film's story was developed over several months, with Joseph working closely with the cast and crew to bring the script to life.

The film's cinematography was handled by Satheesh Kurup, who has worked on several Malayalam films in the past. The movie's editing was done by V.S. Vinayak, who has edited several of Jeethu Joseph's previous films.

#Music

The film's music was composed by Anil Johnson, who has worked on several Malayalam films in the past. The movie's soundtrack features several songs, including the hit single "Ore Pakal", which was sung by M.G. Sreekumar.

The film's background score was composed by Anil Johnson, who worked closely with Jeethu Joseph to create a score that would complement the movie's tense and suspenseful atmosphere.

#Reception

##Critical response

The film received positive reviews from critics, with many praising the movie's tense and suspenseful storyline. The film's performances were also praised, with Mohanlal and Meena receiving particular praise for their performances.

The Times of India gave the film 4 out of 5 stars, praising the movie's "gripping" storyline and "superb" performances. The Hindu praised the film's "taut" direction and "excellent" performances.

##Box office

The film was a commercial success, grossing over ₹100 crore at the box office. The movie performed well in Kerala, where it was released on over 200 screens.

The film's success can be attributed to the popularity of the first film, as well as the strong word-of-mouth that the movie received. The film's tense and suspenseful storyline, combined with the strong performances of the cast, helped to make it a hit with audiences.

#Accolades

The film received several awards and nominations, including the Kerala Film Critics Association Award for Best Film. The movie also received several nominations at the Asianet Film Awards, including Best Film and Best Director.

#Notes

The film's success has led to speculation about a possible third installment in the Drishyam franchise. Jeethu Joseph has said that he is open to the idea of making another film, but has not confirmed any plans.

The film's success has also led to a renewed interest in the original film, with many viewers going back to watch the first movie after seeing the sequel.

article:
Backlash (2023)
================

Backlash was a professional wrestling event produced by WWE, a global entertainment company. It took place on May 6, 2023, at the Coliseo de Puerto Rico in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The event was the 17th event under the Backlash chronology and featured wrestlers from the Raw and SmackDown brands.

Production
-----------
### Background

Backlash was first announced on January 16, 2023, via WWE's social media accounts. The event marked the company's return to Puerto Rico for the first time since 2005. Tickets for the event went on sale on January 20, 2023, and quickly sold out.

### Storylines

The event featured several storylines from both Raw and SmackDown. One of the main storylines going into the event was the feud between Cody Rhodes and Brock Lesnar. The two had been at odds for several weeks, with Rhodes looking to avenge his loss to Lesnar at WrestleMania 39.

Another notable storyline was the rivalry between Bianca Belair and Iyo Sky. The two had been competing against each other for several months, with Belair looking to retain her Raw Women's Championship.

Event
------
### Preliminary matches

The event kicked off with a match between Sami Zayn and JD McDonagh. The two had been feuding for several weeks, with Zayn looking to gain momentum heading into the event. In the end, Zayn emerged victorious, pinning McDonagh after a Helluva Kick.

The next match saw Liv Morgan and Raquel Rodriguez take on the team of Ronda Rousey and Shayna Baszler. The two teams had been at odds for several weeks, with Morgan and Rodriguez looking to gain a much-needed win. In the end, Morgan and Rodriguez emerged victorious, pinning Baszler after a Senton.

### Main event

The main event of the evening saw Cody Rhodes take on Brock Lesnar for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship. The two had been at odds for several weeks, with Rhodes looking to avenge his loss to Lesnar at WrestleMania 39. In the end, Lesnar emerged victorious, pinning Rhodes after an F-5.

Reception
----------

The event received generally positive reviews from fans and critics. Many praised the event for its strong match card and well-executed storylines. However, some criticized the event for its lack of surprises and predictable outcomes.

Aftermath
----------

### Raw

The following night on Raw, Cody Rhodes addressed his loss to Brock Lesnar. Rhodes praised Lesnar for his skills, but vowed to one day become the Undisputed WWE Universal Champion.

Meanwhile, Bianca Belair celebrated her successful title defense against Iyo Sky. Belair praised Sky for her skills, but warned her that she would not be giving up her title anytime soon.

### SmackDown

On the following episode of SmackDown, Sami Zayn celebrated his win over JD McDonagh. Zayn praised McDonagh for his skills, but warned him that he would not be able to hang with the likes of him and other top superstars.

Meanwhile, Liv Morgan and Raquel Rodriguez celebrated their win over Ronda Rousey and Shayna Baszler. The two praised each other for their skills and vowed to continue their winning ways.

Results
-------

* Sami Zayn defeated JD McDonagh
* Liv Morgan and Raquel Rodriguez defeated Ronda Rousey and Shayna Baszler
* Bianca Belair defeated Iyo Sky to retain the Raw Women's Championship
* Cody Rhodes was defeated by Brock Lesnar for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship

article:
Cyclone Freddy

Cyclone Freddy was a powerful and long-lived tropical cyclone that affected several countries in the Indian Ocean and southeastern Africa in February and March 2023. The cyclone's impact was felt across the Mascarene Islands, Madagascar, Mozambique, Malawi, and other parts of mainland Africa, causing widespread damage and loss of life.

# Meteorological history

Cyclone Freddy formed as a tropical low in the Indian Ocean on February 4, 2023, approximately 1,000 km (620 miles) north of Mauritius. The system gradually intensified as it moved west-southwest, becoming a tropical cyclone on February 6. Over the next few days, Freddy continued to strengthen, reaching Category 4-equivalent intensity on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

## Records

Cyclone Freddy holds several records, including the longest-lived tropical cyclone in the Indian Ocean, with a lifespan of 37 days. It also reached Category 5-equivalent intensity, making it one of the strongest tropical cyclones in the region.

# Preparations

As Cyclone Freddy approached the Mascarene Islands and the African mainland, several countries took measures to prepare for the storm's impact.

## Mauritius

Mauritian authorities declared a state of emergency on February 9, with the storm expected to make landfall on February 10. Evacuation centers were set up, and residents were advised to stock up on food and water. The Mauritius Meteorological Services issued regular updates, warning of strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges.

## Réunion

Réunion Island, a French overseas department, also took precautions, with authorities declaring a state of emergency on February 9. Evacuation centers were set up, and residents were advised to stay indoors during the storm.

## Madagascar

Madagascar's government declared a state of emergency on February 12, as the storm approached the island's eastern coast. Evacuation centers were set up, and residents were advised to move to higher ground. The Malagasy authorities also warned of the risk of landslides and flooding.

## Mozambique

Mozambican authorities declared a state of emergency on February 14, with the storm expected to make landfall on February 15. Evacuation centers were set up, and residents were advised to move to higher ground. The Mozambican National Institute of Meteorology issued regular updates, warning of strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges.

## Malawi

Malawian authorities declared a state of emergency on February 15, as the storm approached the country's southern border. Evacuation centers were set up, and residents were advised to move to higher ground. The Malawian Department of Meteorological Services issued regular updates, warning of strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges.

# Impact

Cyclone Freddy made landfall in Madagascar on February 16, causing widespread damage and loss of life. The storm then moved west, affecting Mozambique, Malawi, and other parts of mainland Africa.

## Mascarene Islands

Cyclone Freddy passed close to the Mascarene Islands, causing significant damage to Mauritius and Réunion. Strong winds, heavy rainfall, and storm surges affected both islands, with widespread power outages and property damage reported.

## Madagascar

Madagascar was severely affected by Cyclone Freddy, with widespread damage reported across the island. The storm caused significant flooding, landslides, and damage to infrastructure. The Malagasy government reported at least 100 deaths and over 100,000 displaced persons.

## Mozambique

Mozambique was also severely affected by Cyclone Freddy, with widespread damage reported across the country. The storm caused significant flooding, landslides, and damage to infrastructure. The Mozambican government reported at least 50 deaths and over 50,000 displaced persons.

## Malawi

Malawi was also affected by Cyclone Freddy, with widespread damage reported across the country. The storm caused significant flooding, landslides, and damage to infrastructure. The Malawian government reported at least 20 deaths and over 10,000 displaced persons.

## Elsewhere in mainland Africa

Other parts of mainland Africa were also affected by Cyclone Freddy, including Zimbabwe, Zambia, and South Africa. The storm caused significant rainfall, flooding, and damage to infrastructure in these countries.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of Cyclone Freddy saw a significant response from governments, international organizations, and humanitarian agencies.

## Madagascar

The Malagasy government declared a state of emergency, with the United Nations, the European Union, and other international organizations providing assistance. Humanitarian agencies, including the Red Cross and Médecins Sans Frontières, also provided aid to affected communities.

## Mozambique

The Mozambican government declared a state of emergency, with the United Nations, the European Union, and other international organizations providing assistance. Humanitarian agencies, including the Red Cross and Médecins Sans Frontières, also provided aid to affected communities.

## Malawi

The Malawian government declared a state of emergency, with the United Nations, the European Union, and other international organizations providing assistance. Humanitarian agencies, including the Red Cross and Médecins Sans Frontières, also provided aid to affected communities.

Tournament

The 2023 All England Open was held at the Utilita Arena Birmingham, which has a seating capacity of over 15,000 spectators. The venue has hosted the tournament since 1994 and has undergone several renovations and expansions to become one of the premier badminton venues in the world.

### Point distribution

The 2023 All England Open was a BWF Super 1000 tournament, which means that it offered the highest level of ranking points outside of the BWF World Championships. The point distribution for the tournament was as follows:

* Semi-finalist: 8,400 points
* Quarter-finalist: 6,600 points

article:
2022 National League Championship Series

The 2022 National League Championship Series (NLCS) was the best-of-seven game series in Major League Baseball (MLB) that determined the National League (NL) champion for the 2022 season. The series was played between the Philadelphia Phillies and the San Diego Padres, with the Phillies ultimately emerging as champions.

#Background

The 2022 NLCS was the 53rd edition of the National League Championship Series, which was established in 1969. The series was played between the winners of the two National League Division Series (NLDS). The Phillies defeated the Atlanta Braves in the NLDS, while the Padres defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers. The series was a rematch of the 1983 NLCS, which was won by the Phillies.

#Summary

The Phillies dominated the series, winning in five games. They won the first two games at home, and then took a 3-1 lead in the series with a win in Game 4 on the road. The Padres staved off elimination with a win in Game 5, but the Phillies closed out the series with a win in Game 5 at home.

##Game summaries

###Game 1

Game 1 was played on October 18, 2022, at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Phillies took an early lead, scoring three runs in the first inning on a home run by Bryce Harper and a single by Kyle Schwarber. The Padres cut the lead to 3-2 in the top of the fifth inning, but the Phillies added two more runs in the bottom of the inning to take a 5-2 lead. The Padres scored two runs in the top of the ninth inning, but the Phillies held on for a 5-4 win.

###Game 2

Game 2 was played on October 19, 2022, at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Phillies took a 2-0 lead in the bottom of the third inning on a home run by Rhys Hoskins. The Padres cut the lead to 2-1 in the top of the fifth inning, but the Phillies added two more runs in the bottom of the inning to take a 4-1 lead. The Padres scored two runs in the top of the ninth inning, but the Phillies held on for a 4-3 win.

###Game 3

Game 3 was played on October 21, 2022, at Petco Park in San Diego, California. The Padres took a 2-0 lead in the bottom of the third inning on a home run by Manny Machado. The Phillies cut the lead to 2-1 in the top of the fifth inning, but the Padres added two more runs in the bottom of the inning to take a 4-1 lead. The Phillies scored two runs in the top of the eighth inning, but the Padres held on for a 4-3 win.

###Game 4

Game 4 was played on October 22, 2022, at Petco Park in San Diego, California. The Phillies took a 2-0 lead in the top of the third inning on a home run by J.T. Realmuto. The Padres cut the lead to 2-1 in the bottom of the fifth inning, but the Phillies added two more runs in the top of the eighth inning to take a 4-1 lead. The Padres scored one run in the bottom of the ninth inning, but the Phillies held on for a 4-2 win.

###Game 5

Game 5 was played on October 23, 2022, at Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Padres took a 2-0 lead in the top of the third inning on a home run by Juan Soto. The Phillies cut the lead to 2-1 in the bottom of the fifth inning, but the Padres added two more runs in the top of the eighth inning to take a 4-1 lead. The Phillies scored two runs in the bottom of the eighth inning, but the Padres held on for a 4-3 win.

###Composite line score

Philadelphia Phillies (5) - 24 runs, 44 hits, 4 errors
San Diego Padres (1) - 20 runs, 37 hits, 5 errors

article:
The Voice (American TV series) season 23

The twenty-third season of the American reality television series The Voice premiered on March 6, 2023, on NBC. The season concluded on May 23, 2023. Blake Shelton, Kelly Clarkson, Chance the Rapper, and Niall Horan returned as coaches for the season, with Carson Daly returning as the host.

# Overview

## Development

In May 2022, NBC announced that The Voice had been renewed for a twenty-third season. In November 2022, it was announced that Chance the Rapper and Niall Horan would be joining the show as new coaches, replacing former coaches John Legend and Gwen Stefani. This marked the first time that Horan and Chance the Rapper had served as coaches on the show.

## Coaches and host

Blake Shelton and Kelly Clarkson returned as coaches for their eleventh and ninth seasons, respectively. Chance the Rapper and Niall Horan joined the show as new coaches, marking their first season. Carson Daly returned as host for his twenty-third season.

## Mega mentor

In February 2023, it was announced that Dan + Shay would be serving as the season's mega mentor. The duo worked with all four teams during the Knockout rounds.

## Additions and changes

This season saw the return of the "Steal" and "Save" options during the Battles and Knockouts, respectively. The "Steal" allows a coach to steal a contestant from another team, while the "Save" allows a coach to save one of their own contestants from elimination.

## Promotion

The season was heavily promoted through various social media platforms, including Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook. The show's official Twitter account released several teasers and sneak peeks leading up to the premiere.

# Teams

The season began with four teams, each consisting of 17 contestants. The teams were led by their respective coaches: Team Blake, Team Kelly, Team Chance, and Team Niall.

# Blind auditions

The Blind auditions took place over the course of six episodes, with each coach selecting 17 contestants for their team.

## Episode 1 (March 6)

The first episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 6, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a four-chair turn from contestant Alex.

## Episode 2 (March 7)

The second episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 7, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a three-chair turn from contestant Maya.

## Episode 3 (March 13)

The third episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 13, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a four-chair turn from contestant Ethan.

## Episode 4 (March 14)

The fourth episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 14, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a three-chair turn from contestant Lily.

## Episode 5 (March 20)

The fifth episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 20, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a four-chair turn from contestant Jackson.

## Episode 6 (March 21)

The sixth and final episode of the Blind auditions premiered on March 21, 2023. The episode featured performances from several contestants, including a three-chair turn from contestant Ava.

# Battles

The Battles took place over the course of three episodes, with each coach pairing contestants from their team to compete against each other. The Battles allowed each coach to narrow down their team to 8 contestants.

## Notes

During the Battles, each coach had the option to "Steal" a contestant from another team.

# Knockouts

The Knockouts took place over the course of two episodes, with each coach pairing contestants from their team to compete against each other. The Knockouts allowed each coach to narrow down their team to 4 contestants.

## Notes

During the Knockouts, each coach had the option to "Save" one of their own contestants from elimination. Dan + Shay served as the season's mega mentor, working with all four teams during the Knockouts.

# Playoffs

The Playoffs took place over the course of one episode, with each team performing. The episode allowed the coaches to narrow down their team to 2 contestants.

# Live shows

The Live shows took place over the course of two episodes, with the top contestants competing against each other.

## Week 1: Top 8 – Semi-finals (May 15)

The first Live show of the season premiered on May 15, 2023. The episode featured performances from the top 8 contestants, with the public voting to determine the top 4 contestants.

## Week 2: Finale (May 22–23)

The second and final Live show of the season premiered on May 22, 2023. The episode featured performances from the top 4 contestants, with the public voting to determine the winner. The winner was announced on May 23, 2023.

Croatia national football team

The Croatia national football team represents Croatia in international football matches and is controlled by the Croatian Football Federation, the governing body for football in Croatia. The team has been a member of FIFA since 1941 and UEFA since 1993, and has been competing in international competitions since 1994.

# History

## Official formation

The modern Croatian national team was formed in 1990, following the country's declaration of independence from Yugoslavia. The team played its first friendly match against the United States on October 17, 1990, in Zagreb. However, the team's official formation was recognized by FIFA and UEFA in 1993, after the country gained international recognition.

## Blažević period (1994–1999)

Miroslav Blažević was appointed as the team's first manager in 1994, and led the team to its first major international tournament, the 1996 European Championship. The team finished third in the tournament, losing to Germany in the semi-finals. Blažević's tenure also saw the team qualify for its first World Cup in 1998, where it reached the semi-finals, where it lost to France.

## Jozić, Barić and Kranjčar period (2000–2006)

After Blažević's departure, the team was managed by three different managers: Mirko Jozić, Otto Barić, and Zlatko Kranjčar. During this period, the team qualified for two European Championships (2004 and 2008) and one World Cup (2002), but failed to advance to the knockout stages.

## Bilić period (2006–2012)

Slaven Bilić took over as manager in 2006 and led the team to two European Championships (2008 and 2012) and one World Cup (2010). The team's best finish during this period was reaching the quarter-finals of the 2008 European Championship, where it lost to Turkey.

## Štimac, Kovač and Čačić period (2012–2017)

After Bilić's departure, the team was managed by Igor Štimac, Niko Kovač, and Ante Čačić. During this period, the team qualified for one European Championship (2016) and one World Cup (2014), but failed to advance to the knockout stages.

## Dalić period (since 2017)

Zlatko Dalić took over as manager in 2017 and led the team to the 2018 World Cup, where it finished runners-up, losing to France in the final. The team also qualified for the 2020 European Championship and the 2022 World Cup.

# Image

## Kits

The Croatia national team's kits have traditionally been red and white checkered, with blue shorts and socks. The team's away kits have varied over the years, but have often featured a white or blue shirt with red and white checkered shorts and socks.

## Supporters

The Croatia national team has a passionate and dedicated fan base, known for their vocal support and colorful displays. The team's supporters are often referred to as the "Vatreni" (meaning "The Fiery Ones" in Croatian).

## Charity

The Croatia national team has been involved in several charity initiatives over the years, including supporting children's hospitals and participating in fundraising matches for various causes.

# Stadiums

The Croatia national team plays its home matches at various stadiums across the country, including the Stadion Maksimir in Zagreb, the Stadion Poljud in Split, and the Stadion Gradski vrt in Osijek.

Atiq Ahmed
================

Atiq Ahmed was an Indian politician and a former member of the Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Parliament of India. He was a prominent figure in the politics of Uttar Pradesh, particularly in the Allahabad region. Ahmed's life was marred by controversy, with multiple criminal cases lodged against him, including murder and abduction charges.

Early and Personal Life
------------------------

Atiq Ahmed was born on August 10, 1962, in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, India. His father, Ashraf Ahmed, was a small-scale businessman, and his mother, Rehana Begum, was a homemaker. Ahmed grew up in a middle-class family and was the youngest of five siblings. He received his primary education at a local school in Allahabad and later attended the Ewing Christian College, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree.

Ahmed's interest in politics began at a young age, and he was influenced by his father's involvement in local politics. He was known to be charismatic and had a strong presence, which helped him build a network of supporters in his community.

Political Career
-----------------

### Entry into Politics

Ahmed's entry into politics was facilitated by his family's connections with local politicians. He began his career as a member of the Indian National Congress (INC) and quickly rose through the ranks. In 1989, he was elected as a member of the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha) from the Allahabad West constituency.

Ahmed's tenure in the Vidhan Sabha was marked by controversy, with allegations of involvement in organized crime and extortion. Despite this, he maintained a strong support base in his constituency and was re-elected in 1991.

### As a Member of Lok Sabha

In 1996, Ahmed was elected as a member of the Lok Sabha from the Phulpur constituency in Allahabad. He was re-elected in 1998 and 1999, representing the same constituency. During his tenure in the Lok Sabha, Ahmed was a member of the INC and later joined the Samajwadi Party (SP).

Ahmed's time in the Lok Sabha was marked by frequent disruptions and altercations with fellow parliamentarians. He was known for his aggressive behavior and was often at the center of controversies.

### Participation from Prison

In 2007, Ahmed was arrested and jailed in connection with the murder of Raju Pal, a BSP MLA from Lucknow. Despite being behind bars, Ahmed continued to participate in politics, contesting and winning elections from prison.

Joe Martin (orangutan)

Joe Martin was a male orangutan who gained fame in the early 20th century for his performances in film and theater. He was one of the first orangutans to be featured in the entertainment industry, and his career spanned over a decade. During his time in the spotlight, Joe Martin was known for his intelligence, agility, and charismatic personality.

#Background

Orangutans, native to Indonesia and Malaysia, were a rare sight in the Western world during the early 20th century. However, with the rise of the entertainment industry, there was a growing demand for exotic animals to be featured in films and stage shows. Joe Martin was one of the first orangutans to be brought to the United States for the purpose of entertainment.

Joe Martin was born in the wild, likely in the jungles of Borneo or Sumatra. He was captured at a young age and shipped to the United States, where he was sold to a private owner. The incident was widely reported in the press, and it led to a reevaluation of the safety protocols for working with animals on film sets.

The incident led to a lawsuit against Joe Martin's owners, who were accused of negligence.

Clerkenwell Crime Syndicate

The Clerkenwell crime syndicate, also known as the Adams Family or the Clerkenwell Cartel, is a notorious British organized crime syndicate based in Clerkenwell, London. The group's origins date back to the 1970s, and they have been involved in various forms of crime, including extortion, money laundering, and narcotics trafficking. The syndicate's activities have been the subject of extensive media coverage and law enforcement investigations over the years.

# Background

The Clerkenwell crime syndicate emerged in the 1970s, in the midst of a wave of gangland violence and turf wars in London. The group's early activities were centered around extortion, with members targeting local businesses and individuals for protection money. As the syndicate grew in power and influence, they began to expand their operations into other areas, including narcotics trafficking and money laundering.

The syndicate's rise to prominence was largely due to the leadership of the Adams family, who would become the dominant force within the organization. The family's patriarch, Terry Adams, was a charismatic and ruthless leader who was instrumental in building the syndicate's reputation and expanding its operations.

article:
Sonic the Hedgehog 2 (film)

Sonic the Hedgehog 2 is a 2022 live-action/animated action-comedy film directed by Jeff Fowler and written by Pat Casey and Josh Miller. It is the sequel to the 2020 film Sonic the Hedgehog and is based on the video game franchise of the same name by Sega.

# Plot

The film takes place after the events of the first film. Sonic (voiced by Ben Schwartz) is struggling to balance his desire for adventure and his need for a normal life in Green Hills, Montana. Meanwhile, Dr. Robotnik (played by Jim Carrey) has escaped from prison and is seeking revenge against Sonic and his friends.

Robotnik teams up with Knuckles (voiced by Idris Elba), a powerful echidna who is determined to protect the Master Emerald, a powerful artifact that is hidden on a remote island. Sonic and his friends, including Tails (voiced by Colleen O'Shaughnessey) and Tom Wachowski (played by James Marsden), must work together to stop Robotnik and Knuckles from obtaining the Master Emerald and using its power to destroy the world.

# Cast

## Voice cast

* Ben Schwartz as Sonic the Hedgehog
* Colleen O'Shaughnessey as Miles "Tails" Prower
* Idris Elba as Knuckles the Echidna
* Lee Majdoub as Agent Stone

## Live-action cast

* James Marsden as Tom Wachowski
* Jim Carrey as Dr. Robotnik
* Tika Sumpter as Maddie Wachowski
* Adam Pally as Wade Whipple
* Shemar Moore as Randall Handel
* Natasha Rothwell as Rachel

# Production

## Development

In May 2020, it was announced that a sequel to the first film was in development, with Jeff Fowler set to return as director and Pat Casey and Josh Miller set to return as writers. The film was officially greenlit in July 2020, with production set to begin in 2021.

## Casting

In December 2020, it was announced that Idris Elba had been cast as Knuckles, a new character in the film. In January 2021, it was announced that Colleen O'Shaughnessey had been cast as Tails, another new character in the film.

## Filming, visual effects and animation

Principal photography began in March 2021 and wrapped in May 2021. The film was shot in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. The visual effects and animation were provided by Moving Picture Company, with the company's Vancouver studio serving as the lead studio.

## Music

The film's score was composed by Tom Holkenborg, who also composed the score for the first film. The soundtrack features several songs, including "Stars" by Coldplay and "U Can't Touch This" by MC Hammer.

# Release

## Marketing

The film's marketing campaign began in December 2021, with the release of the first trailer. The trailer featured footage of Sonic, Tails, and Knuckles, as well as a glimpse of the film's villain, Dr. Robotnik.

## Theatrical

Sonic the Hedgehog 2 was released in the United States on April 8, 2022, by Paramount Pictures. The film was released in several other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia, in the following weeks.

## Home media

The film was released on digital platforms on May 24, 2022, and on DVD and Blu-ray on August 9, 2022.

# Reception

## Box office

Sonic the Hedgehog 2 grossed over $400 million worldwide, making it one of the highest-grossing films of 2022. The film grossed over $170 million in the United States and over $230 million in other countries.

## Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences, visuals, and performances. The film holds a 69% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 222 reviews, with an average rating of 6.2/10.

## Accolades

The film was nominated for several awards, including a Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Visual Effects and a Saturn Award for Best Visual Effects.

# Sequel

In April 2022, it was announced that a third Sonic film was in development, with Jeff Fowler set to return as director and Pat Casey and Josh Miller set to return as writers. The film is currently in production and is set to be released in 2024.

article:
2023 Ukrainian Counteroffensive

The 2023 Ukrainian counteroffensive was a series of military operations launched by the Ukrainian Armed Forces against the Russian occupation of Ukraine, starting in June 2023. The counteroffensive aimed to regain control of territories lost to Russia since the 2022 invasion and to weaken the Russian military presence in the region.

# Background

## State of the war

By the spring of 2023, the war in Ukraine had been ongoing for over a year, with both sides suffering significant losses. article:
Typhoon Hinnamnor
================

Typhoon Hinnamnor was a powerful tropical cyclone that affected Japan and South Korea in September 2022. The storm was the eleventh tropical cyclone and the sixth typhoon of the 2022 Pacific typhoon season. Hinnamnor was a large and intense system that brought significant damage and disruption to the affected regions.

Meteorological history
-------------------

Typhoon Hinnamnor formed as a tropical depression on August 26, 2022, over the western Pacific Ocean, approximately 1,000 km (620 mi) east of the Philippines. The system gradually intensified as it moved northwestward, becoming a tropical storm on August 28. Hinnamnor continued to strengthen, reaching typhoon intensity on August 30.

As Hinnamnor approached the Ryukyu Islands, it underwent rapid intensification, with its maximum sustained winds increasing from 120 km/h (75 mph) to 215 km/h (134 mph) in just 24 hours. The storm reached its peak intensity on September 1, with maximum sustained winds of 230 km/h (143 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 920 hPa (27.17 inHg).

Preparations
------------

### Japan

As Hinnamnor approached Japan, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) issued warnings and advisories for the Ryukyu Islands and southern Kyushu. The Japanese government evacuated over 1,000 residents from low-lying areas and islands, and more than 100 flights were canceled.

### South Korea

In South Korea, the Korea Meteorological Administration (KMA) issued a typhoon warning for the southern coast, including the cities of Busan and Ulsan. The Korean government evacuated over 10,000 residents from coastal areas and issued a high alert for the entire country.

### Elsewhere

In Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical storm warning for the eastern coast, while the Philippines' National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC) placed several provinces under a state of alert.

Impact
------

### Japan

Typhoon Hinnamnor made landfall on the island of Okinawa on September 1, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall. The storm caused widespread power outages, with over 100,000 households affected. Several buildings were damaged, and a few people were injured.

In the city of Naha, the capital of Okinawa Prefecture, strong winds knocked down trees and power lines, causing chaos and disruption. The city's airport was closed, and several flights were canceled.

### South Korea

Hinnamnor made landfall on the southern coast of South Korea on September 2, bringing strong winds and heavy rainfall. The storm caused widespread damage, with over 10,000 households affected by power outages.

In the city of Busan, strong winds knocked down trees and power lines, causing chaos and disruption. The city's port was closed, and several ships were damaged. In the city of Ulsan, several buildings were damaged, and a few people were injured.

### Elsewhere

In Taiwan, the storm brought strong winds and heavy rainfall, causing several power outages and property damage. In the Philippines, the storm caused several landslides and flash floods, resulting in a few casualties.

Retirement
----------

The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) retired the name Hinnamnor from the list of tropical cyclone names in the western Pacific Ocean, due to the significant damage and disruption caused by the storm.

article:
2022 NHL Entry Draft

The 2022 NHL Entry Draft was the 60th NHL Entry Draft. The draft took place on July 7-8, 2022, at the Bell Centre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.

# Eligibility
The 2022 NHL Entry Draft was open to players born between January 1, 2002, and September 15, 2004. Players who were not selected in the 2020 NHL Entry Draft but were eligible for the 2022 draft were also included. To be eligible, North American players had to be 18 years old by September 15, 2022, while European players had to be 19 years old by the same date. Players who were already drafted in the 2020 NHL Entry Draft but were not signed to an NHL contract were also eligible for the 2022 draft.

# Draft Lottery
The NHL conducted a lottery to determine the top three picks in the draft. The 16 teams that failed to qualify for the 2022 Stanley Cup Playoffs were entered into the lottery. The lottery was held on May 10, 2022, and the Montreal Canadiens won the first overall pick. The New Jersey Devils won the second overall pick, and the Arizona Coyotes won the third overall pick.

# Top Prospects
Several players were considered top prospects for the 2022 NHL Entry Draft. Some of the most notable players included:

* Juraj Slafkovský, a Slovakian left wing who played for TPS of the Finnish Liiga
* Logan Cooley, an American center who played for the USNTDP of the USHL
* Luke Hughes, an American defenseman who played for the University of Michigan of the Big Ten Conference
* Simon Edvinsson, a Swedish defenseman who played for Frölunda HC of the SHL
* David Jiříček, a Czech defenseman who played for HC Škoda Plzeň of the Czech Extraliga

# Selections by Round
The 2022 NHL Entry Draft was a two-day event, with the first round taking place on July 7 and rounds two through seven taking place on July 8.

## Round One
The first round of the draft took place on July 7, 2022. The Montreal Canadiens selected Juraj Slafkovský with the first overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Simon Nemec with the second overall pick. The Arizona Coyotes selected Logan Cooley with the third overall pick.

## Round Two
The second round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The New Jersey Devils selected Seamus Casey with the 46th overall pick. The Arizona Coyotes selected Filip Bystedt with the 48th overall pick. The Montreal Canadiens selected Owen Beck with the 33rd overall pick.

## Round Three
The third round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The Montreal Canadiens selected Miguël Tourigny with the 69th overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Ty Nelson with the 68th overall pick. The Arizona Coyotes selected Michael Buchinger with the 70th overall pick.

## Round Four
The fourth round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The Arizona Coyotes selected Rasmus Korhonen with the 96th overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Brody Lamb with the 104th overall pick. The Montreal Canadiens selected Isaac Belliveau with the 103rd overall pick.

## Round Five
The fifth round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The Montreal Canadiens selected Jared Davidson with the 130th overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Jakub Malek with the 137th overall pick. The Arizona Coyotes selected Justin Robidas with the 141st overall pick.

## Round Six
The sixth round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The Arizona Coyotes selected Maksymilian Szuber with the 163rd overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Viktor Hurtig with the 166th overall pick. The Montreal Canadiens selected Jared Wright with the 169th overall pick.

## Round Seven
The seventh round of the draft took place on July 8, 2022. The Montreal Canadiens selected Petteri Nurmi with the 203rd overall pick. The New Jersey Devils selected Zakhar Bardakov with the 208th overall pick. The Arizona Coyotes selected Adam Žlnka with the 212th overall pick.

The championships featured competition in 46 events, including 23 events for men and women, and 2 mixed events.

Qualification
------------

The qualification period for the championships began on July 1, 2021, and ended on November 30, 2022. Swimmers who achieved the qualification standard in their respective events were eligible to compete. The qualification standards were set by FINA, and were based on the results of the 2019 FINA World Swimming Championships (25 m).

The championships took place over six days, from December 13 to 18, 2022. The competition schedule included morning and evening sessions, with the morning sessions featuring heats and the evening sessions featuring finals.

A total of 46 events were contested at the championships, with 23 events for men and women, and 2 mixed events.
